article.Body:
India’s public sector banks are facing a severe capital crunch resulting from a mountain of bad loans.

According to industry estimates, total capital requirement of the 23 state-owned banks with nearly 73 percent of assets among them, would shoot up to approximately Rs 180,000 crore by FY19.

To ease the pressure, the government recently announced a plan to infuse Rs 70,000 crore into public sector banks (PSBs) over the four years leading up to FY19.  This amount will be split into four tranches of 25,000 crore each for the current and next fiscal and Rs 10,000 crore each for the following two fiscals.

However, the catch is that the infusion will restrict access to fresh capital infusion for poorly managed banks.

Accordingly, it is expected that the budget 2015-16 would see Rs 25,000 crore allocated for recapitalisation. However, it remains to be seen whether the promised funding will actually happen.

This also needs to be seen in context of the previous budgeted allocations. In 2014-15, the government ended up infusing only about Rs 6,990 crore, compared to the budgeted Rs 11,200 crore. Similarly, despite the mounting worry, the initial budgeted allocation for 2015-16 was only Rs 7,940 crore
